item.title: Exposing Kubernetes Services Securely with Cloudflare Tunnels
item.description:
In my last post, I deliberately skipped over how I use Cloudflare Tunnels to expose this blog running on Kubernetes to the internet.

As promised, let’s have a look at how this works.

Exposing a server to the internet Link to heading

Cloudflare Tunnels are an offering from Cloudflare which lets you expose webservers to the internet without opening any firewall ports, or even revealing your IP address.

item.title: Hello World | Hosting this Blog on Kubernetes
item.description:
This post was automatically deployed to my blog. All I had to do was write some markdown and commit.

Overview Link to heading

I am using the static site generator hugo with the hugo-coder theme. This means I can focus on writing / deploying my blog without worrying about CSS and JavaScript.

This blog is defined in a git repo and deployed on Kubernetes with manifests in my (private) gitops/infra repo. I’ll share the relevant snippets inline here.
